turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- concluding part of this -- pardon me Your Honor?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I did not attempt to say that it is in fact simple.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I didn't quite understand what you're --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: In -- in his motion, he's -- he refers to the fact that he signed statements of some kind to evidence payments.
My observation was, and I think that was an error because it did not so state the court having objected or the court having sustained an objection to the question, "Did you sign receipts?"
On -- on the other hand, I state that it is the fact.
He did sign receipts.
Then the motion concluded --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Are they the ones that are lost or destroyed?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Oh, no, sir.
No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You haven't come to that yet?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir, not yet.
Defendant request that these reports be delivered to counsel for the defendant on excised and for further use to cross-examination.

The Government objected to the motion on the basis that -- that receipts were administrative records of the Government that they weren't statements within the meaning of the Jencks statute since they had no content.
They didn't speak.
I think the idea was as that they were narrative statements of the witness.
That they didn't, that they were remote, they didn't relate to his direct testimony.

However, the Government offered to produced to the defense a schedule of payments, schedule which had been prepared by the Federal Bureau of Investigation which itemized month by month the amounts paid and whether for services for expenses.
The defense counsel upon that proper by the Governor inquired, and this is on 551 in the transcript, with the schedule contained, if I may ask, the items for which reimbursement was made.
And the Assistant United States Attorney replied, "I do not believe that they do and it is my impression that neither do the receipts.
I know that the schedule contains the dates of payments and the amounts from the beginning to the end”.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did the schedule, Mr. Maroney, break down the expenses as to date and so forth or did it just say so much -- so much for salary and so much for expenses?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: It was in that form Your Honor and I think it's broken down month by month.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: In other words, April 1951 --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- $25 salary under the salary column or --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes, salary and maybe $15 under the expenses.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But they didn't say so many dollars expenses for -- for the day he was visiting with --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No,sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: X or Y or anything that kind.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Would you mind telling cutting through all the ticket of words?
What it is regarding the disbursements made by the Government to an informing witness?
What it is that the -- that the defendants asked and that the Government was ready to give and what he receives for duty?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: The Government was ready to give a -- a compilation that had been prepared which stated how much money had been paid month by month to each of these witnesses.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Total of, as the Chief Justice just brought out.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Not -- not itemized?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Not itemized and indicating whether or not the particular payment was for services or for expenses.
Now, the expense listing did not say that $5 of the $15 was for attendings of the C.P. convention or what -- whatever.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They were bulk item, bulk (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: A bulk items.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, what is it the defendants wanted?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Now, the defendants wanted any reports that the witness had made concerning his expenditures and the receipts signed by the witnesses for moneys received from the F.B.I. for services and for expenses.
Now, the Government --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Was there any controversy or any overt controversy between the Government and the defendant that the disclosures that the Government was ready to make as to the moneys it paid at the informers, both for salary and for expenses differed from that for which receipts were obtained?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir.
There was no -- no suggestion that there was a difference.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But it was suggested by the defendant, did they call into question the -- the truthfulness, of the completeness of the Government readiness, the figures that the Government are ready to give or did give?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir, there was no suggestion that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Then what is the controversy about just whether they were in fact receipts --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: And -- and as to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is deposited with the F.B.I. or some other agency for the moneys which in a month the Government disclosed, is that right?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right.
And -- and the defense reasoning for refusing to reject the preferred schedule was that it didn't itemize the particularized expenses.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose though --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask you --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I suppose though if the -- if the witness had said to the F.B.I. agent, "Now, I -- I expended $25 on one day because I was -- I was attending this convention and $20 the next day because I was in some other place”.
And there was something in the testim -- in his testimony that conflicted with the -- with that.It would be very important to the defendant to know that, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: It -- it might in the circumstances of --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It might.
Well it would.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- particular case.
Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: It would, wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I think in your hypothetical situation or a -- a case that it would.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, if you just got the -- if you just got the -- the totals of the items that he gave to the agent, he wouldn't be getting very much, would he?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, not -- not if there were documents which in fact were statements or our statements and which would do what Your Honor supposes in -- in the hypothetical would be accomplished.
In other words --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did the Government -- did the Government deny such hypothesis that the Chief Justice put to you?Did the Government say that the receipts are just as much in the large total as the figures he had given to you?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That -- that's right, Your Honor.
The --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What was it?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- the Government --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I -- you can't say it's right because I'm asking a question.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well -- well, the Government stated in reply to a question from defense counsel that the schedule is not itemized and neither do the receipts.
And now --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And that is not the fact (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: And -- and that we now find, unfortunately, is not the fact.
And it is for that reason primarily.
And -- and the reason that with the record in that state, the trial court denied the motion, I don't know that he did it because of that fact.
And the Court of Appeals sustained or affirmed the conviction believing that could be the fact.

Now, we now know in preparing our brief on the merits here that 9, 9 of the 123 receipts that are in existence and that are involved here do itemize in a cryptic form and we have tried to give the Court, now in page 26, I think, of the brief, an example of the nature of those nine receipts.
Now, all the nine -- all those nine receipts are Ondrejka receipts.
There are a total, I think, of 61 receipts that Ondrejka signed, most are in a standard receipt form.
It says, "Received from special agent”, so and so “$25 for services during the month of April, signed, Michael J. Ondrejka”.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather the Government however, do I correctly understand that now concedes that for the purposes of production of the statute, this form of receipt is a statement.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: We concede that it is a statement Your Honor.
We do not concede that these --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That is irrelevant.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- particular statements --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- sufficiently relate to --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- the direct testimony -- that's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: That's what I understood it.

And the reason you suggest sending it back for a hearing before the District Judge, if I understand it correctly, is that you want the opportunity to show that while these are statements within the statute, they are not related to the subject matter of the witnesses' testimony and for that reason and not for this.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that this --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Plus (Voice Overlap)--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: -- that even if related, it was not prejudicial error to exclude.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: And if -- if related in -- it's possible that in two or three particulars, as we pointed out here for example, a reference to an L.Y.L. meeting, might be said in a re -- remote sense to have been related to his testimony concerning an L.Y.L. meeting that if the Court were to decide that it did relate in that narrow or -- or very broad sense, our argument is that there was no prejudice thereby to the defendant because of the fact primarily that he had the narrative reports that the witness made to the F.B.I. concerning the activities about which he testified on cross-examination.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But these are arguments that you want to make to the District Court as I understand it, which court, we -- well unlike us, have the -- all these statements before us.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's correct.
We don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you think --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- we don't make those arguments here Your Honor to -- in an effort to ask the Court to affirm here.

We think that the state of the record is such, that it can only be fully developed and we think that in the peculiar circumstances of this particular case, it would be appropriate for this Court to remand to permit full develop of the record with respect to the situation in this particular --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You said a minute ago, Mr. Maroney, that the -- the trial court denied the motion for the production of these receipts, you don't know for what reason.

Now, I suppose the reason you -- the reason you asked this Court to send it now back is because that certainly because its an easy assumption that he might have ruled otherwise had he known that 9 out of 123, but you said 9 out of -- and I don't question the figures before us, that 9 out of 123 receipts did particularize.

And it's the most plausible assume that -- not assumption but most plausible consideration that he might say, “Well, I know bibliophiles who collected a manuscript, as a rule where there are some manuscripts get some more”.

And so, if there are nine and these were overlooked in the first call, well how do you know of more careful pseudonym might deduce small or what you call cryptic disclosures might -- this defendant counsel might find cryptic -- some cryptic signs on their receipts, they're not suggesting that.
Now in relation to that since we're dealing here with a -- with a trial in the federal court with all the so-called "supervisory authority" we are at to meet the irrelevant to inquire.
How do you -- how does it come about that such an error was made?
Is it that -- well, you have, in view with a lot of documents that out of the district.

Would the District Attorney phone down and probably or write to the F.B.I. and slipped the General's office (Inaudible) the criminal division whatever it is and search would be made here and they would then be advised, can U.S. attorney would have a right to rely on that?
Could you shed some light on that?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I think --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: How do these things happen apart from the facts of human (Inaudible) explains a lot in this world?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: It is -- it is normal practice in -- in this type of case where there are informants testifying that the F.B.I. will prepare in advance a trial, one of these schedules of payments.
And in addition, the -- the Bureau will ordinarily also prepare photostatic copies or at least one photostatic copy of the original receipts.

Usually, they will be maintained more or less in -- in readiness just in case they should be called for because I think that it's clear to all of us that these are fairly peripheral types of statements.

In other words -- of course, the narrative statements, the reports that the witness has made concerning his -- his activities in the party and about which is going to be called upon to testify, those are prepared by the trial attorneys in advance and they -- they confer with the F.B.I. on what should be exci -- what the Government should ask for excisions on and the concentration is on the narrative statements.
However, I understand that here as in the usual case, the F.B.I. had prepared these photostatic copies.
And that they were in the F.B. --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Of the receipts -- of the receipts?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Of the receipts -- of the receipts.
And that they were in the F.B.I. field office.
I understand they were not in court.
They didn't have in court, the -- the Government attorneys.

And when this arose and the Assistant United States Attorney made this representation, he was doing it on the basis of information that he had received, I suppose, in conversations with other attorneys perhaps and maybe some F.B.I. agents working on the case.
Now --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well then that could be at some point by somebody, reference to the documents deposited in Washington, isn't that right?
I don't mean to say that that's the --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I think these are usually kept in the field office.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Oh, they're kept in the field office, right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But I don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But many are somewhere these are deposited and U.S. attorneys and his assistants must've conferred with the responsible person in charge of these documents, isn't that right?
Well, if not elucidating.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I think they probably asked the F.B.I. maybe even in memorandum form --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's right (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- to procure or make photostatic copies in case we need them.
Now, in this particular instance, I understand from --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: From finish to this Mr. Maroney, he would ask a field office to prepare these and fit you as you said a minute ago, the attorneys would regard this as peripheral, he wouldn't actually say, "Let me see all these receipts, may it be deposited in the field office," and he probably would have some verbal or telephonic exchange with the field office and say what of -- what do these receipts show --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- is that right?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the way the thing would happen and the field officer would tell him, "They just show the amounts”.
And he may have gone through -- I'm speculating now --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That could happen, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And he may have gone through 20 and 30 and saw nothing but the totals and therefore assume the other hundred had the same total, is that right?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right, sir.
I -- I think that -- if --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, this is an (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- of course if you weren't careful here, --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- it would be easy --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- to -- to come to the conclusion that these are straight receipts all the way through.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, this isn't as simple as that Mr. -- just -- just (Inaudible) that receipts of the kind that you illustrate in that but might be have a very important bearing on the whereabouts of the Government witness on a particular day when he says it was on a certain place that's following about a certain thing.
And it is difficult for me to understand why even if that was the procedure which kept the originals from the -- whoever tried the case, was it why something wasn't done about it?
Why it was before the Court of Appeals?
Certainly, you -- you had to know this issue was going to be before the Court of Appeals.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, in -- in the Court of Appeals, the Government's brief was prepared I think partly here in Washington, partly in Chicago and the attorneys who worked on the brief relied strictly on the record as we did in the brief in opposition in this Court.
And it was only when the Court grant a certiorari limited to these questions.
I -- I think we, in our brief in opposition, we hardly mentioned receipts.
Well, I think our argument, first of our argument on the production concerned, the narrative reports of the witness and -- and the questions that were raised thereon, the excisions and so forth.

And it was -- in preparing the brief on the merits, that the attorney preparing the original draft, prepared a memorandum requesting from the F.B.I. copies of the receipts that are involved -- were involved in the case.
And it's -- it was then and going through the receipts, it was found out that some of the receipts do itemize.
I -- I might say that from my own experience, I think that it is a fairly unusual thing that receipts of informants do itemize in -- in this respect.
Now, I -- I think this is one thing that possibly the trial court might inquire into and might take into consideration with respect to the obligation that the Government had at the trial here.
He might inquire as to the general practice as to the prevailing situation and possibly taking into consideration the -- the diligence of the Government.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, the (Inaudible) of the issue between you and your adversaries on this Jencks find is simply this, isn't it?

But you say it ought to go back so that the Court -- whatever the District Court does, it comes back to this Court ultimately and the district attorney doesn't grant a new trial that we can then decide the case knowing what the facts are.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And your adversaries saying now, that kind of a -- investigation is not necessarily ought to reverse (Inaudible) of the trial now.
That's the whole issue between you, isn't it on this?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: On this point, I think that essentially is the issue, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Maroney, may I ask this.

According to your latest brief, do I understand that the position of the Government is that it is normal practice for an informer of this kind to state to an agent of the F.B.I. what his expenses are, itemized -- itemizing them for him and then the -- the agent turns that amount in and immediately destroys the -- the record which would show what the informer told him were his expenses.
Do I understand that's the normal practice?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Where he is called upon to itemize to the agent or where he does is a practice itemized to the agent.
It may be that the same procedure that was followed here is followed.
But, for example, take Sullivan's receipts, he testified that his arrangement with the F.B.I. was that he received a certain amount of money.

I think -- let's say $75 and the understanding with him was that $10 of that amount would be deemed to cover his expenses so that all of Sullivan's receipts or everyone of them just says received of special agents so and so $75 for services.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's the same as any -- any officer when he gets a -- when he gets a voucher when he's paid for either his salary or his expenses, it comes in a bulk amount.

It isn't -- it isn't itemized but I don't know of any -- any expenditure by any employee or the officer of the Government that doesn't require some itemization to be -- that's retained by the Government as evidence of the fact that -- that he actually made those expenditures.

And I just want to know now if maybe their -- the way they deal with undercover agents but I'm just asking you if it is the practice to -- for the agents to -- to ask them what their expenses are and -- and for what purpose and then when he gets the information, destroys records immediately so there'd be no records available in the Government of that fact.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Your Honor, I -- I think that this type of thing --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The only reason I asked you that is because you say according to the regular factors, it was done here.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, according to the regular practice?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: I so -- I so understood the -- your brief.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I -- I said that according to my experience, it would be more unusual to have itemized receipts.
As a matter of fact, I think it's --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No, I'm not -- I'm not talking about --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- quite unusual to have itemized receipts.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- I'm not talking about receipts.
I'm talking about the -- the information that the Government gets of what his expenditures are and you say that the only evidence the Government gets is what he told the agent.
And then, after the -- the agent makes a memorandum of it and turns the gross amount in, he immediately destroys the -- the information that he got.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, of course here where the -- where the informant apparently was called upon to itemize, the agent did make a few notes which -- which we think clearly, in the nature of things, would not amount to a statement under the -- under 3500.
And on the basis of those notes, he would incorporate it in the receipts.
Now, that's seems apparently what happened here so that there isn't a destruction of the records in a situation where the agent was asking and requiring the informant to itemize.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, is it that --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: What -- what I -- what I meant to point out was that -- that it's probably the more usual procedure.
I hate to generalize because I don't know how many informants there are or what the practices in -- in these respects in all cases are but --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, there certainly would be some --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Certainly, this is a very usual type of receipt.

The -- the Sullivan receipt, it -- it says, “I received $75” and he is supposed to absorb if he has to pay $2 for literature or pay 50 cents for dues, he is supposed to absorb those ordinary expenses out of his -- out of his money --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All I was trying to find out --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- all I was trying to find out, what is the practice?
You stated what the practice was and you stated that these -- these notes were destroyed in accordance with practice.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: The notes?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now -- yes.
Now, where -- where he does itemize it?
Is he supposed to keep it, the agent, keep the -- keep the notes?
Make -- the record he makes of it?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: In this -- in -- in this particular --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: No -- no, just tell me the practice.
I know I don't -- not being (Voice Overlap)--

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Your Honor as I said, I hesitate to generalize an -- an appeal in which I certainly necessarily have a limited amount of knowledge which would only go to informants and witnesses with whom I have -- have -- have been acquainted.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, didn't your brief say that this was done in accordance with practice?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well then, what -- what do you base that on?
Just tell us what you based that statement on and I won't go any further with it.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: I think it's on page 24 of your brief, Mr. Maroney, the first whole paragraph, the last couple of sentences I think is (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes.

We -- we based it on the information that we have -- that we received from the Federal Bureau of Investigation asking what the procedure was with respect to these two witnesses as to the method of reporting expenses -- the method of recording expenses whether or not any oral or any notes of agents of expenses have been retained or what the situation is actually here with respect to the existence and non-existence of any statements or notes.
And the F.B.I. advised us that neither Ondrejka nor Sullivan submitted written expense accounts.
They also stated that in some instances, Ondrejka orally furnished the contacting agent with a breakdown of his expenses incurred during the pertinent period prior to the date of payment.
The agent then prepared a receipt and in some instances, the breakdown of expenses was incorporated into the receipt and in some instances, the expenses were shown only as a lump sum.
After the receipts were prepared, any notes, the contacting agents may have had were destroyed.
In the case of Sullivan, no breakdown of expenses was maintained.
And Your Honor, what -- what I have been trying to say is that in the usual situation, the informant receiving so much money per month is called upon to absorb his ordinary expenses.
In -- in -- with respect to Ondrejka, he was apparently at a later time -- his -- his early receipts don't show any breakdown.
They just show “received $25 for expenses”.
There is no breakdown.
It's only the last nine receipts covering about a two-year period.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You mean chronologically for that?

You mean, whoever went through in these receipts went through a hundred and whatever nine (Inaudible) -- 114 and calmed down and sort of got tired and stopped, (Inaudible) in chronological or in physical order or whatever it is?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I think -- well actually, that covers the period from June of 1950 to May of 1953.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Was that the period in dispute here?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes, sir, large -- largely that period.
The early receipts of Ondrejka prior to 1950 don't show an itemization.
Now, that runs for a -- during the year or beginning at September 1949 until May of 1950.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But were those -- those --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Then -- then apparently in June of 1950, he started itemizing and the agent incorporated the itemizations in the receipt were had he -- had not done as prior there, too.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, the period -- the period where there was no itemization was not in -- was not in question here was it?
And the -- and the indictments say that he was -- he was a -- a member of the party from such and such a time to such and such a time and wasn't that in the 1950's?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That he was a member of the party on December 11, 1952.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: The day they executed the (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I have to say that the whole period was involved because the Government's proof was that he had been a member for a few years prior to 1952 and he continued to be a member until 1953.
And Ondrejka in his testimony spent that -- that crucial date of the execution in filing of the affidavit.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, just one more question and I won't take anymore of your -- any more of your time.
But I would like to ask you if these -- if these notes that were taken by the agent itemizing the expenses of -- of this witness are the notes that you referred to as the personal notes of the agent?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes, sir.
They would be -- as we understand the situation, the Ondrejka might be talking to an agent on the phone several days before they were -- they would get together.
And he would mention that he had the following expenses and the agent would jot down a few notes as to what those expenses were.
And those expenses apparently, were incorporated into the receipt that was prepared.
Now sometimes, too apparent and of course, Your Honors will appreciate that these facts even we have not fully developed because there are many details that -- that could be developed here I think.

Sometimes that they would meet and Ondrejka, at that point, would tell the agent what his expenses had been and the agent would let on the spot prepare a receipt, pay him the money and Ondrejka would sign the receipt.

Now, we -- we think that in -- in the nature of thing, the -- the notes that an agent may have made while Ondrejka was listing or telling him what expenses he had incurred would only be what -- what I call a cryptic itemization.
L.Y.L. party and the witness probably would've said in the -- in the middle of August, I went to a labor youth league party and we all had to contribute $2 and we had to buy this or that.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You think that would make it personal?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I -- I think it's -- it's certainly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What would he use -- what would he use that information for?
He'd use it to pay the man, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: He'd use it to pay him and to later incorporate into the receipt --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, into the receipt.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- in certain instances --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, how -- how --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- which he did.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- why do -- why do you classify that as personal?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, I'd -- it's personal in the sense Your Honor that he is not making it to become a Government record.

In other words, if in the course of an investigation, a detective jots down a telephone number that he gets from a -- from somebody he interviews or he jots down a license plate or he makes a few notes as to some leads he wants to follow, they're -- they're notes -- he certainly acting as a Government agent but they're -- they're not made to become a part of a Government file.
They're -- they're notes that he makes for his -- for the performance of his personal duty.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Personal duties?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Personal, I mean they're -- they're on behalf of the Government but I mean they're his --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And they're -- and they're made --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- personal obligation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- they're made as the basis for paying a man Government money, are they not?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right.
But I -- but I think Your Honor --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: How come --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- that they are made much as if an attorney seating in a court, would jot down a few notes that he wants to -- to mention and argue something.
Certainly, he is not making notes to go back and put in a file.
And ordinarily, at the conclusion of the argument, he will probably throw them in a waste basket.
They're -- they're notes that he makes to remind him of something.
In -- in this -- in this case, I think it's clear that he probably made notes and then from the notes, he made these itemizations on receipts.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Did he pay the money out and destroyed the notes which left him with no verification of any kind as to why he paid this money to this man?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well Your Honor, on -- on these nine receipts, there is a verification that these -- these itemizations, L.Y.L. party, party literature, things of that sort, this is the verification --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- that he secured from the informant.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Would you say here that he destroyed the notes, the personal notes in a normal course of operation.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's right, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Maroney, I take it you're just the -- the contents of the F.B.I. and what you tell us about their practice, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And what you've read, I take it as what they have furnished you as your -- that it were your instructions or your -- as their -- as the basis of your response to any question that might be asked or any argument that you might make, is that right?
What you've read a little while ago, 10 minutes ago.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: What I have -- what I have read --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, in the course of that, you said the notes or the practice of destroying the notes, would you mind referring to that?
It's on the second page I think if you turn to page --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- something about destroying notes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: The -- the agent then prepared a receipt and in some instances, the breakdown of expenses was incorporated into the receipt.
And in some instances, the expenses were shown only as a lump sum.
After the receipts were prepared, any notes the contacting agents may have had were destroyed.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, is that -- is that -- that -- about that, what I asked you, does that mean merely ad hoc with reference to this case or does that -- is that intended, as you understand it, as an expression of what the course of business is?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: As I understand it Your Honor, it's the course of business.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Course of business.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That this kind of a note, especially the agent's original notes would not be normally retained.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, the other question I want to ask you is that -- do you happen to know whether the director of the F.B.I. must state as other Government official's statement that come before appropriations committee that -- that permitted appropriations committee the -- the expenditures made for informant -- informants?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: As to my understanding, he does not, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: He does not.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there a law -- I -- I was mentioning that -- I think that some special law probably, as I judged on what you said, which authorizes the F.B.I. to pay out mo --Government money to informants who claim they have expended in various places without having any record of it at all?
That can be used by anybody else.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: It's -- it's my understanding, Your Honor, that there is a certain amount of money appropriated which does not have to be accounted for.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's true --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that the law authorizes this?
I may --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: The law --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I may --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Congress -- Congress has appropriated it for that purpose so that it doesn't have to be accounted for.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's true of the F.B.I. and the C.I.A., isn't it?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That's correct, sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And addressed (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I think probably most law enforcement agency --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the Government and the President's private fund, so-called “private fund”, the public credit.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) and in this case have the notes until they got the receipt, of the receipts to describe or the -- the note to describe, is (Inaudible) only after the receipts.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, at least after they were prepared the -- in other words, the notes might be used so that the -- just so the agent him -- for his only information as it did with Ondrejka.

Now, if this were his particular practice with his particular informant that when the informant itemized for him, he would -- he then as he did here, trans -- transposed those original notes to the receipt itself and it became a part of the receipt.
Apparently, with respect to other instances and other informants, there was no itemization possibly in some instances, none was requested.

For example, Sullivan's arrangement whereby he understood that $10 of the money he received was to cover his ordinary expenses as -- as an informant or as a -- going around to the party meetings and buying literatures and so forth.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Do you happen to know from a -- whether there's any difference on the practice on these notes now as between pre-Jencks, post-Jencks period is -- is what you read there from the F.B.I. related to pre-Jencks or post-Jencks?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, not with respect to -- I'm not sure of the precise practice on notes of the expense -- expenses such as this.
I'm sure that policy is to retain notes of interviews and things of that sort, as that -- whereas that -- that may not usually have been done in the past.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, as you understand it, everything that we've been talking about here is pre-Jencks.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Oh, this -- this entire situation is pre-Jencks.
This case was tried prior to the -- first tried, prior to the Jencks decision and had been affirmed in the Court of Appeals when the Court of Appeals on rehearing.
On the basis of Jencks reversed the first conviction so that everything that is involved here with respect to statements had to occur prior to the Jencks decision.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do I understand from your (Inaudible) and I think I gather and maybe it's right, maybe that's what our opinion held that no statement, no -- no evidence, written evidence from a Government record which is not a "statement" within the meaning of the Jencks rule can ever be summoned and brought into Court?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well you seem to have concluded that each time with the statement with -- with this argument that is not a statement within the Jencks case.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: No, sir.
We -- we concede that these are his statements because they're --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- assigned by the witness.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- what part of it?
You said it would not be unless certain things could be shown to them.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, if it were not signed by the witness.

In other words, or -- or there was no evidence that he had adopted or signed that he had accepted it as his own words then I'd make the definition of the Jencks statute that it would have to be substantially verbatim would -- would apply.
That's -- that's why I said --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- that I don't think that the agents' notes would be statements because they -- they --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose their statement --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- I don't think they would be substantially verbatim.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- suppose that they were not signed by, what about that?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: If they were not signed?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: If they're not signed by the witness then I think the statute requires that the statement be substantially verbatim.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And all be what?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: To be substantially verbatim.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or adopted by him.

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Or -- or adopted.
And -- and -- in other words, if they are just few notes of summarizing in keywords a conversation, that is not a statement under the Jencks statute.
I think this Court has so held.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it's still a little difficult for me to understand even though papers may not be kept as they've known that they are going to be a witness, why statement relating to what they have done in connection with the activities which they will testify should be habitually destroyed?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I think it's important in this particular case to -- to understand that -- that these reports, if you want to call them reports, to the agent concerning expenses were not made with -- with the view in mind that the -- the informant was thereby reporting some activity --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But he wanted --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- which would.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: but he wanted --

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: -- would be incorporated into an investigative file.
That -- that part of his -- those parts of his reports would be submitted in the form of a written statement.
I think the witness is here, both of them testified that they reported on every activity they went to.

That when they would go to a Communist Party meeting, when they went to a convention, that they would submit to the F.B.I. a written report, sometimes handwritten, sometimes they would orally report to the agent.
The agent would then make a summary of what he -- the witness had told him.
Those are the narrative statements which were produced here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What -- what statement -- what evidence do you think could show that this particular statement were not relevant?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I think -- I think in the context in which we are now that probably in examination by the trial judge would be the appropriate way for that determination.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about the weight, I'm talking about what do you think could be introduced that would show they were not relevant if you had relate to expense that he have incurred which he reported what he was doing in connection to this examination?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: I think an examination of the statements themselves will show that they do not relate to the subject matter of --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do not relate in what way?

turn.speaker: kevin_t_maroney
turn.label: Mr. Kevin T. Maroney
turn.text: That they -- that they don't concern -- well they don't touch upon the activities about which he has testified on direct examination.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: We'll recess now, Mr. Maroney.
